title: EPIALES
content:
EPIALES was the personified spirit (daimon) of nightmares. He was also known as the melas
          oneiros "black dream". Epiales was probably numbered amongst the Oneiroi (Dream-Spirits), sons of the goddess Nyx (Night).

The Greek word epialês was derived from the verb epiallô "to lay upon."

Greek Lyric I Alcaeus, Frag 406 (from Etymologicum Genuinum 151) :
        "The words epialos, epiales and epioles denote (1) the feverish chill (2) the
        daimon who assaults sleepers.
        Homer and most writers have epioles with the e; the form in -os means something
        different, namely the feverish chill . . . Alkaios (Alcaeus) called it epialos.
        Apollonios says that Epialtes itself (the nighmare daimon) is called Epiales and by a change of a to
        o Epioles."

Aeschylus, Suppliant Women 886 ff (trans. Weir Smyth) (Greek tragedy C5th B.C.)
          :
        "[The goddess Gaia (Earth) is invoked to drive away a nightmare :] Like a spider, he [a rapist] is carrying
        me [a woman] seaward step by step--a nightmare (oneiros), a black nightmare (melas oneiros)!
        Oh! Oh! Mother Earth (Ma Ge), mother Earth (Ma Ge), avert his fearful cries! O father Zeus, son of Ge
        (Earth)!"

Other references not currently quoted here: Phrynincus Comicus 1, Dioscorides 3.140, Artemidorus 2.37,
          Rufus ap. Orib. 7.26.177, Strabo 1.2.8.
